lesson.title: Animating Visualizations
lesson.summary: Students will use datasets for animating data and build out animations with Tableau pages and get introduced to Flourish.

atoms.text:
## So Why Animations?

The late Hans Rosling was an award-winning Swedish physician, academic, statistician, and public speaker, a professor of International Health, and the founder of the Gapminder Foundation. He was a renowned public speaker, and delivered numerous TED talks on global development. Shortly after his death, his book Factfulness was published. 

His firm Gapminder developed a software tool called Trendalyzer that allowed people to explore relationships between world indicator data points. He famously __set data to motion__ in the TED talk __“The best stats you've ever seen”__ and debunked several myths about world development. 

Hans Rosling was a master data storyteller, and much of what we’ll try to do in the coming two lessons is channel his passion, energy and skill to weave animated data into stories that bring data to life.

## Animating Using Tableau Pages

Tableau allows you to animate your visualization, and the following demonstration demonstrates how to do that.

question.prompt: To best compare access to basic sanitation with the rise of mobile phone subscriptions, where would you drag and drop the “Mobile Cellular Subscriptions per 100” field?

atoms.title: exercise 1
atoms.text:
## Exercise 1: Animating Using Tableau Pages
In the first exercise, we’ll create a basic scatterplot and then we’ll use the Tableau Pages shelf to set the marks in our scatterplot into motion. Finally, we’ll adjust the Pages controls to add and format tails.

#### Instructions:

1. Connect a new Tableau Public workbook to the text file `“PhonesWaterSanitation.csv”`. The file is located towards the bottom of this page.
2. Create a scatterplot with Mobile Cellular Subscriptions on the y-axis, Basic Sanitation Access on the x-axis, and a circle for each country sized by Population and colored by Region
3. Add Year to the Pages shelf and click the `Play` button to animate the scatterplot. 
4. Use the Pages control to add and format tails

atoms.title: Comparing Flourish vs. Tableau
atoms.text:
## Comparing Tableau to Flourish

Tableau and Flourish are two very powerful data storytelling tools that have similarities and differences. They can be seen used to complement each other rather than just to replace each other, and they each have their own areas of strength. 

__Tableau Public__ allows users to connect to raw data and find interesting data stories. However, while it’s possible to create animations in the application, the “play” button does not appear in the browser after publishing*.

__Flourish__ is a data storytelling tool that’s best to use when you have formatted your data and you know what chart types to use in your data story. It has smooth animation and ability to add audio files for sharing data stories in the browser.

## More about Flourish
Flourish was created by the team at Kiln, an award-winning data studio that has created data story projects for clients like The Guardian, BBC and the Financial Times. 

Flourish provides a free version that, similar to Tableau Public, requires publishing work to the public domain. They also provide a commercial version that allows people with proprietary data, such as at companies, to keep their work private, and also do things like download the full HTML code of the projects they create.

Flourish allows users to quickly converts spreadsheets into "stunning online charts, maps and interactive stories" as described  by Flourish. It doesn’t require any coding, and it focuses on enabling storytelling and animation of data. It allows users to either share directly or embed visualizations and stories on their own websites. 

In this course, we’ll make use of the free version, and create projects using data that’s already in the public domain.

atoms.title: Quiz - which column would you choose

question.prompt:
Let’s say you want to create a scatterplot using the Flourish Bubble Chart template, and you want the vertical axis to show the percent of energy consumed by each country that comes from renewable energy sources. The data for “Renewable energy consumption (% of energy)” is contained in Column I. 

Where do you put Column I in the “Select columns to visualize” panel to the right of the Flourish editor?

atoms.text:
## Exercise #2: Create a Flourish visualization and import your data and select columns

The purpose of this exercise is to learn how to create a simple chart in Flourish using the bubble chart template and world indicators data obtained from the World Bank’s data website. 

#### Instructions:
1. Create a new Bubble chart in your Flourish account
2. Replace the sample data with the data in “PhonesWaterSanitation.csv”
3. Use the following mappings to map your data to the Bubble chart template elements

#### Columns to Visualize:

* X Values: Basic Sanitation Access
* Y  Values: Mobile Cellular Subscriptions
* Name: Country Name
* Color: Region
* Size: Population
* Time: Year
* Series: Country Name
* Filter Control: Income Group

atoms.title: Exercise 3 instruction
atoms.text:
## Exercise #3: Formatting your visualization in Flourish

The goal of this third exercise is to complete the creation of our bubble chart in Flourish by changing various design elements such as axis labels and formats to match the data we uploaded into the template, instead of matching the sample data that was there when we first opened the template. 

#### Instructions:
1. Edit the x-axis to not be log scale, going from min 0 to max 100, and titled “Access to Basic Sanitation (percent)”
2. Edit the y-axis to not be log scale, going from min 0 to max 250, and titled “Mobile Cellular Subscriptions (per 100 people)”
3. Add a descriptive header Title and Subtitle that introduces your audience to the story
4. Add “World Bank” as the source in the Footer

atoms.title: Exercise 4
atoms.text:
## Exercise #4: Animating your Flourish visualization

In this simple exercise, we’ll set our data in motion using the Play button in Flourish.

#### Instructions:
1. In your Bubble chart in Flourish, click the Play button in the top right corner to set your data in motion
2. To speed it up or slow it down, go to the Time Slider area of the formatting pane on the right and play with the “Time between steps when playing” control. 
3. Try it at 0.25 seconds, or 1.0 seconds. Which do you prefer?

## Exercise #4: Animating your Flourish visualization

In this simple exercise, we’ll set our data in motion using the Play button in Flourish.

#### Instructions:
1. In your Bubble chart in Flourish, click the Play button in the top right corner to set your data in motion
2. To speed it up or slow it down, go to the Time Slider area of the formatting pane on the right and play with the “Time between steps when playing” control. 
3. Try it at 0.25 seconds, or 1.0 seconds. Which do you prefer?

## Challenge Exercise

Now that you have been shown how to create a bubble chart in Flourish, here is a challenge exercise for you. Try creating a different type of chart in Flourish using any of the other chart templates in Flourish. For instance, try creating a Horserace chart or using the Bar chart race template. 

As you work on these other charts, pay attention to how the data is structured in the sample visualization, and create a version of this chart using the data provided for the exercises in this lesson.

For example, you might want to create an animated bar chart that shows the countries that have the highest GDP per capita over time, such as in this [project](https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/316276/). 

### Restructuring the data for each chart template
As you take on this exercise you will notice that restructuring the data is an important, and often the most time-consuming, aspect of building data visualizations. Each type of chart template requires the data to be structured differently. Sometimes you need to transform the data, create pivot tables. 

If you are a veteran data analyst or data scientist, this will not be new to you. However, if you need some additional resources on data transformations, here are links to some Udacity courses videos that can walk you through the data transformation lessons. Keep in mind, these are part of other courses. 

* [Pivot tables](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd098/parts/5966ce46-17c7-4491-9856-6fa905d02a83/modules/28f776f2-89c3-417c-8569-41b59a2df372/lessons/054ce6a5-668d-480f-889c-fc1a2763e33d/concepts/33f791f6-de2c-4b58-aca8-89030e634caa)
* [Conditional Aggregation](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd098/parts/5966ce46-17c7-4491-9856-6fa905d02a83/modules/28f776f2-89c3-417c-8569-41b59a2df372/lessons/054ce6a5-668d-480f-889c-fc1a2763e33d/concepts/6e30786c-6b06-41c4-823d-e9eedca3b4c8)

atoms.title: Other Tools to Animate
atoms.text:
There are other powerful tools and programming languages that can be used to create animated charts and graphs from your data. The following list provides other tools and links to learn how to animate data using tools other than Tableau Public and Flourish:

## R and RStudio
* [R and RStudio](https://www.analyticsvidhya.com/blog/2017/06/a-study-on-global-seismic-activity-between-1965-and-2016/?htm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+AnalyticsVidhya+%28Analytics+Vidhya%29) are common ones that most data analysts use.
* Check out this blog that teaches you how to [create animations in R using the tween package in R studio](https://blog.revolutionanalytics.com/2017/05/tweenr.html)
* Gganimate also has a blog on how to [create plot animations in R](https://www.datanovia.com/en/blog/gganimate-how-to-create-plots-with-beautiful-animation-in-r/)

### MS PowerBI:
* MS PowerBI is another tool that can create [scatter and bubble charts](https://www.mssqltips.com/sqlservertip/4694/power-bi-animated-scatter-and-bubble-charts/)

### Google’s Data GIF Maker:
And then there is one by Google. Google's Data GIF Maker 
* [datagifmaker](https://datagifmaker.withgoogle.com/)
* [Blog on Google](https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/google-news-initiative/make-your-own-data-gifs-our-new-too/)
#### A sneak peek into what's coming in the next lesson
